Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether it is just and equitable to grant an extension of time to object to the Notice of Ascertained Forfeiture
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Application for extension of time after missed deadline
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Minor two-day delay due to lawyer's computational error
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant must show bona fide intention and that it is just and equitable
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Prompt action by Mr. Heron after realizing delay
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Extension allowed under s. 129.2 if within one year, bona fide intent, and just and equitable
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Miscalculation of 90-day deadline by legal counsel
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Objection deemed timely upon court order
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of filing, reason for delay, lack of prejudice to Minister
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Sought extension from Minister and then Federal Court
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavit or statement explaining delay
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Extension of time to file objection

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether it is just and equitable to grant an extension of time to object to the Notice of Ascertained Forfeiture
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Application for extension of time after missed deadline
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Minor two-day delay due to lawyer's computational error
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant must show bona fide intention and that it is just and equitable
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Prompt action by Mr. Heron after realizing delay
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Extension allowed under s. 129.2 if within one year, bona fide intent, and just and equitable
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Miscalculation of deadline by legal counsel
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Objection deemed timely upon court order
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of filing, reason for delay, lack of prejudice to Minister
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Sought extension from Minister and then Federal Court
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavit or statement explaining delay
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Extension of time to file objection

Application_Facts: Respondents knew of applicant's criminal charges since March 2011 but failed to inform counsel until October 2011; delay attributed to 'inadvertent oversight'
Misrepresentation_Element: Failure to timely disclose known criminal charges
Procedural_Issue: Motion for extension of time to file further affidavits
Evidence_Used: Knowledge of criminal charges from March 2011
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of reasonable explanation for delay in filing
Credibility_Assessment: Arguments of clean hands, futility, and credibility deemed inadequate by court
Outcome: No extension granted, costs not awarded
Relief_Sought: Extension of time to file further affidavits
Remedy_Sought: Permission to submit additional affidavits regarding new criminal charges
Legal_Standard_Applied: Rule 8: Continuing intention, merit, no prejudice, reasonable explanation for delay
Decision_Rationale: Delay due to 'inadvertent oversight' found insufficient; no reasonable explanation provided; negotiations over detention did not justify late disclosure

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section of IRPA relating to criminality and deportation
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant was convicted of mischief, deported, and later acquitted; challenged deportation order based on acquittal
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent resident or foreign national subject to deportation
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Late filing for judicial review without adequate explanation for delay
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal court jurisdiction over immigration matters
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Conviction record, acquittal decision, application for judicial review
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to justify delay in filing judicial review
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not directly assessed; focus on procedural timeliness
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application for extension of time and judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Nullification of deportation order based on subsequent acquittal
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and quashing of deportation order
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Validity of deportation order at time of issuance under IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Deportation order was lawful when issued; subsequent acquittal does not retroactively invalidate it; undue delay in filing
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Division, Immigration Appeal Division, Federal Court

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Low public safety risk given nature of offence
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient at time of conviction; later challenged by acquittal
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Court records, guilty plea, post-acquittal documentation
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Initially credible; later undermined by acquittal but not retroactively applied
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Sentence led to immigration consequences including deportation

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Ms. Kerzner met the criteria under subsection 129.2(4) to extend the time for requesting a Minister's decision
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Application for extension of time to request a Minister's decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: The court found that Mr. Kerzner received the Seizure Receipt and acted on Ms. Kerzner's behalf, establishing constructive notice
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant failed to demonstrate inability to act or bona fide intention within the 90-day period
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Claim of non-receipt of notice undermined by evidence of husbandâ€™s receipt and agency
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Extension under section 129.2 requires (a) application within one year after expiration of original period and (b) demonstration of inability to act or bona fide intention within original 90 days
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Statutory interpretation and application of equitable considerations
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Missed 90-day deadline due to alleged lack of notice and late realization of intent
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Application failed on merits due to lack of timely intention or inability to act
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Seizure Receipt received by husband, actions taken on behalf of Ms. Kerzner
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimed no notice of seizure within 90 days; intention formed only in December 2004
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (Seizure Receipt), agency relationship
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Extension of time to request a Minister's decision

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Ms. Kerzner met the criteria under subsection 129.2(4) to extend the time for requesting a Minister's decision
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Application for extension of time to request a Minister's decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Court found no evidence of inability to act or timely bona fide intention; husbandâ€™s receipt of notice attributed to Ms. Kerzner
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant failed to meet all three criteria under subsection 129.2(4)
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Lack of credible explanation for delay; awareness inferred through spouse's actions
Crimes.Legal_Rule: To obtain extension: (i) inability or bona fide intent within 90 days, (ii) just and equitable, (iii) application made as soon as circumstances permitted
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged ignorance of seizure due to lack of direct notice
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed for failure to satisfy statutory conditions
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Seizure Receipt delivered to husband, no timely action by Ms. Kerzner
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Asserted lack of knowledge of seizure and need for extension due to delayed awareness
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, spousal agency
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Extension of time to challenge seizure decision

Application_Facts: Applicant failed to act within the 90-day period, did not demonstrate inability to act or instruct another person, and lacked a bona fide intention to request a decision. Evidence showed awareness of the NPAs but no action taken.
Procedural_Issue: Failure to meet deadline for requesting a decision on NPAs; application made after 90-day period
Evidence_Used: Evidence showed awareness of the NPAs but no action taken
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failed to demonstrate inability to act or bona fide intention to request a decision
Decision_Outcome: Application for extension of time dismissed
Outcome: Application dismissed, costs awarded to Respondent
Relief_Sought: Extension of time to request a decision of the Minister regarding the NPAs
Legal_Standard_Applied: (a) application within one year after 90-day period; (b) inability to act or bona fide intention; (c) just and equitable; (d) application made as soon as circumstances permitted
Decision_Rationale: Applicant does not meet criteria under subsection 129.2(4) of the Customs Act

Crime_Name: Possession of prohibited weapons or substances
Application_Facts: Mr. Cantell missed the 90-day deadline but applied within one year; claimed distraction due to his wifeâ€™s medical issues
Procedural_Issue: Application for extension of time under section 129.2(4) of the Customs Act
Evidence_Used: Seizure of wine and pepper spray at customs
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence of a bona fide intention to appeal within the initial period
Outcome: Dismissed without costs
Relief_Sought: Extension of time to appeal seizure
Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 129.2(4) of the Customs Act: inability to act, bona fide intention, justness/equity, timely application
Decision_Rationale: Failed to meet statutory criteria under section 129.2(4); second infraction; delay; lack of equitable grounds

Crime_Name: Failure to declare goods at customs
Legal_Issue: Eligibility for extension of time under section 129.2 after missing 90-day deadline
Evidence_Assessment: Personal circumstances cited but insufficient to demonstrate bona fide intention or equitable grounds
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to meet criteria under section 129.2(4)
Legal_Rule: Extension allowed only if applied within one year and meets all conditions: inability to act, bona fide intention, just/equitable, prompt action when possible
Grounds_for_Claim: Personal issues related to wife's medical condition
Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of application; lack of documentation supporting intent or urgency
Legal_Framework: Statutory interpretation of Customs Act provisions on appeals and extensions
Evidence_Type: Affidavit or statement regarding personal circumstances
Remedy_Requested: Extension of time to file appeal
Outcome: Dismissed, Minister's decision upheld
Legal_Provision: Sections 129.1 and 129.2 of the Customs Act
Authority: Minister of Border Security and Organized Crime Reduction; Federal Court

Legal_Issue: Whether the H&C officer applied the correct test for undue, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship
Legal_Rule: The test for humanitarian and compassionate grounds focuses on undue, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship, not solely on risk to life or security
Grounds_for_Claim: Error in applying the hardship test
Legal_Framework: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds provisions in Canadian immigration law
Outcome: Case remitted to a different officer for re-determination

Legal_Issue: Whether the defendant's Skyplume apparatus infringes claims 1 and 2 of the '163 patent
Evidence_Assessment: Expert evidence was used to assess differences in nozzle bifurcation, diffuser presence, and orientation
Decision_Outcome: Defendant's product does not infringe the '163 patent; patent is valid
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiff bore the burden of proving infringement
Credibility_Factor: Expert testimony was considered credible and influential
Legal_Rule: Infringement occurs when all essential elements of a patent claim are reproduced
Standard_of_Review: Objective technical and legal comparison of patent claims
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged unauthorized reproduction of patented invention
Key_Evidence_Considered: Design differences in nozzle, diffuser, and orientation; commercial success of the patent
Legal_Framework: Patent Act (Canada); principles of novelty, utility, non-obviousness
Defendant_Response: Denied infringement and counterclaimed for invalidity and unfair trade practices
Evidence_Type: Technical expert reports, product design documentation
Outcome: Plaintiff's claim dismissed; costs awarded to defendant
Authority: Canadian court with jurisdiction over intellectual property matters

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA officer correctly assessed the applicant's risk of persecution under sections 96 and 97 of IRPA
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted, PRRA decision set aside, case remanded for re-determination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: PRRA officer failed to properly assess credibility of applicant's evidence including past torture and ethnic profiling

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant's fear of persecution due to his wife's arrest constitutes a personal risk under sections 96 and 97 of IRPA
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review after rejection of asylum claims and previous PRRA application

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the PRRA officer correctly assess the applicant's risk of persecution under sections 96 and 97 of IRPA?

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Past torture, discriminatory arrests, lack of state protection as Tamil from Jaffna

Dispute_Type: Permanent residency application based on humanitarian and medical grounds
Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD's decision on medical inadmissibility and humanitarian considerations was reasonable
Evidence_Assessment: Medical evidence of heart conditions indicating potential for excessive demand on health services
Decision_Outcome: IAD's decision upheld; judicial review dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate that exclusion is not warranted despite inadmissibility
Credibility_Factor: Medical stability versus risk of future hospitalization
Legal_Rule: A foreign national is inadmissible if their health condition may cause excessive demand on health or social services
Key_Evidence_Considered: Medical reports on heart conditions, risk of hospitalization, potential healthcare costs
Defendant_Response: Not applicable â€“ decision made by administrative body (IAD)
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to overturn IAD decision, permanent residency approval
Outcome: Application for permanent residency denied; visitor visa suggested as alternative

Legal_Issue: Did the visa officer breach procedural fairness by refusing to award adaptability points for a family relationship?
Evidence_Assessment: Provided documents were inconclusive; applicant failed to provide sufficient proof such as a birth certificate
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate eligibility and familial relationship
Credibility_Factor: Insufficient documentation affected credibility of claim
Legal_Rule: Visa officers must act within their discretion, ensuring procedural fairness and reasonableness in decision-making under immigration regulations
Outcome_on_Merits: No breach of procedural fairness occurred; officer's decision was reasonable
Key_Evidence_Considered: Lack of birth certificate or other conclusive familial documentation
Defendant_Response: Officer acted within discretion based on available evidence
Outcome: Court dismissed the application, upholding the visa officer's decision
Legal_Provision: Procedural fairness and reasonableness under immigration regulations

Dispute_Type: Discovery dispute in patent infringement case
Legal_Issue: Relevance and scope of discovery questions under Federal Court Rules
Evidence_Assessment: Questions related to inducement, commercial success, and hypothetical scenarios assessed for relevance and speculation
Decision_Outcome: Most decisions upheld; two hypothetical questions (3324, 3326) excluded; Gulf States/Deco category ordered to be answered
Burden_of_Proof: On party resisting discovery to show irrelevance or undue burden
Legal_Rule: Rule 458(1): Questions must relate to unadmitted allegations of fact or persons with relevant knowledge
Standard_of_Review: Deferential, unless clearly wrong or vital to final issues
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged patent infringement involving paper plates
Outcome_on_Merits: Partial allowance of appeal; some questions required answers
Key_Evidence_Considered: Discovery questions on inducement, commercial success, hypothetical market behavior
Defendant_Response: Objections to certain discovery questions as irrelevant or speculative
Remedy_Requested: Compel answers to specific discovery questions
Outcome: Appeal allowed in part

Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer's analysis of the child's best interests was reasonable under s. 25(1) of the IRPA

Evidence_Assessment: Assessment of child's best interests, living conditions in Brazil, adequacy of amenities

Crimes.Crime_Name: Providing false information in personal information form

Legal_Issue: Whether the RAD erred in applying a reasonableness standard to review the RPD's decision
Governing_Law: RAD decisions on the standard of review are assessed on correctness
Evidence_Assessment: Key findings were not solely based on applicant testimony
Decision_Outcome: RAD's decision set aside, case remanded for reconsideration

Credibility_Factor: RPD found applicant non-credible, credibility was critical
Legal_Rule: RPD decisions require independent review unless credibility is critical
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard applied incorrectly; correctness standard required for RAD's review
Outcome_on_Merits: Not determined; referred back for reconsideration

Dispute_Type: Employment discrimination, specifically related to dismissal and alleged delay in filing complaint
Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Human Rights Commission erred in dismissing allegations 3 to 6 as out of time and whether the applicant's reasons for delay were sufficient
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant's personal reasons for delay and pursuit of alternate recourse were considered but found insufficient by the Commission
Decision_Outcome: Commission's decision upheld; application for judicial review dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to justify the delay in filing beyond the one-year period
Credibility_Factor: Applicant's explanation for delay included personal circumstances and use of alternate dispute resolution channels
Legal_Rule: Paragraph 41(1)(e) of the Canadian Human Rights Act allows complaints beyond one year if the Commission considers it appropriate
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged discriminatory dismissal by the RCMP
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; case dismissed on procedural grounds due to untimeliness
Key_Evidence_Considered: Date of dismissal (December 19, 2001), date of complaint filing (October 24, 2003), applicant's explanations for delay
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, human rights law, timeliness requirements under federal anti-discrimination legislation
Defendant_Response: RCMP's position not detailed, but Commission accepted procedural bar based on delay
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (dates of employment actions), personal explanations from applicant
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Commission's decision to dismiss the complaint as untimely
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Commission's decision upheld
Legal_Provision: Paragraph 41(1)(e) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court on judicial review

Dispute_Type: Civil dispute over intellectual property rights
Legal_Issue: Whether the defendant's action can be stayed until resolution of a related case involving Cummings Point
Governing_Law: s. 50 of the Federal Court Act
Evidence_Assessment: Defendant sold the accused division prior to providing access to records or personnel; plaintiff retains right to examine defendant despite limited information
Burden_of_Proof: On defendant to demonstrate lack of access to necessary information
Legal_Rule: A stay may be granted under s. 50 of the Federal Court Act only if continuing the action causes prejudice or injustice to the defendant and does not harm the plaintiff
Standard_of_Review: Judicial discretion based on risk of prejudice or injustice
Grounds_for_Claim: Defendant sought stay to avoid duplicate proceedings
Outcome_on_Merits: Stay denied; defendant must proceed with discovery
Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of sale of accused division, availability of records and personnel
Defendant_Response: Requested stay of proceedings pending outcome of related case
Outcome: Stay denied; defendant allowed extended time for discovery arrangements

Legal_Issue: Whether the risk faced by applicants was generalized or specific

Evidence_Ignored: Specific threats and incidents following police report
Legal_Standard: Different in degree from general population risk

Application_Facts: Applicant was absent for 551 days, retained business ties in Colombia, and traveled frequently
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet 1095-day physical presence requirement over 4 years
Evidence_Used: Record of absences (551 days), business ties in Colombia, travel history, Koo factors assessment
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient demonstration of primary connection to Canada
Credibility_Assessment: Absences viewed as a life pattern, not temporary; weak Canadian connections
Outcome: Appeal dismissed
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of citizenship judge's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Koo factors for assessing residency intent
Decision_Rationale: Judge reasonably concluded applicant did not meet residency requirement based on duration and pattern of absences and lack of strong ties to Canada

Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Legal_Provision: Section of IRPA relating to Convention refugee and person in need of protection
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of forced recruitment by LTTE

Application_Facts: Ms. Yani Meilina sought refugee status but was denied due to the RPD's internal flight alternative finding.
Procedural_Issue: The RAD applied the reasonableness standard instead of correctness for questions of central importance; plaintiff did not receive a fair appeal.
Decision_Outcome: RPD denied refugee status; RAD applied incorrect standard but error found not outcome-determinative; court granted judicial review.
Outcome: RAD's decision set aside; case remitted for re-determination by a different member.
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of RAD decision, fair hearing, recognition of refugee status
Remedy_Sought: Re-determination of refugee claim with proper legal standard applied
Standard_of_Review: Correctness standard should have been applied for central legal questions; reasonableness standard applied inappropriately
Decision_Rationale: Although the error in standard of review was non-decisive, the lack of a fair appeal process warranted setting aside the decision.
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Appeal Division (RAD), Refugee Protection Division (RPD)

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: subsection 29(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, missed initial proceedings, later attended with counsel; claimed lack of notice, interpreter issues, and ignored H&C factors.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Claims of inadequate notice, lack of interpreter, and failure to consider H&C
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of immigration officerâ€™s duty in procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Record of non-attendance, counsel representation, demonstrated English comprehension, absence of H&C referral requirement
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: H&C claims not substantiated or required at exclusion stage
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant understood proceedings; interpreter not necessary
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Overturn exclusion order based on procedural unfairness
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Mandatory exclusion for inadmissibility under subsection 29(2)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No obligation to provide interpreter when comprehension evident; H&C considerations separate from exclusion orders

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with residency obligation under section 28
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: section 28 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visitor visa and did not fulfill residency obligations; submitted H&C application but excluded from IAD referral
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant â€“ failed to meet residency obligation
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged failure to consider humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) factors
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority to issue exclusion without IAD referral when inadmissible solely for overstay
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Visa duration records, departure history, submission of H&C application
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: H&C factors not grounds to bypass mandatory exclusion under section 28
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No challenge to credibility; focus on legal applicability
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Exclusion order issued lawfully without IAD referral
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Set aside exclusion order and refer to IAD
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Procedural referral to Immigration Appeal Division
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Mandatory exclusion under IRPA when inadmissible solely for overstay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Section 28 requires exclusion order without IAD referral if inadmissibility is based solely on overstay

Legal_Provision_Violated: Credible fear of persecution based on ethnicity or religion under the Immigration Act
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed refugee status due to alleged discrimination based on Jewish heritage in Armenia
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistent information in PIF, questionable birth certificate authenticity
Procedural_Issue: Credibility assessment during Refugee Division hearing
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of corroborating evidence of persecution in Armenia
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility findings due to inconsistencies and lack of supporting documentation
Decision_Outcome: Refugee status denied by Refugee Division
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Division's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Credible fear of persecution based on protected grounds
Decision_Rationale: Insufficient evidence and credibility issues undermined the claim; no reviewable error found

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD erred in concluding the applicant failed to establish her identity
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's credibility undermined due to unexplained discrepancies in documents
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Inability to verify identity due to inconsistent documentation
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to explain inconsistencies in identity documents
Crimes.Application_Error: Providing inconsistent or conflicting identity documents
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied by Federal Court
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Applicant must establish identity using acceptable documentation
Crimes.Application_Factor: Totality of evidence considered, including corroborating but insufficient evidence
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Suspected misrepresentation through discrepant official documents

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Establish Identity under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD erred in concluding the applicant failed to establish her identity
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: RPD assessed inconsistencies across multiple identity documents
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove identity with credible documentation
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Failure to explain document discrepancies affected credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Applicant must establish identity before the RPD using acceptable documentation
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error in RPDâ€™s identity determination
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to insufficient proof of identity
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA and administrative law principles on reasonableness
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Applicant could not clarify inconsistencies in submitted documents
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial intervention to overturn RPD decision

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Authenticity and consistency of identity documents in refugee claim
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD erred in rejecting the applicantâ€™s identity documents
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credibility undermined by failure to explain document inconsistencies
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Use of potentially false or inconsistent documents affecting identity verification
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Overall irregularities in documentation despite some valid points
Crimes.Application_Error: Submission of discrepant documents without adequate explanation
Crimes.Legal_Standard: RPD must reasonably assess identity based on totality of evidence
Crimes.Application_Factor: Presence of some corroborating evidence outweighed by inconsistencies
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Indications of document falsification or misrepresentation

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether misrepresentation affected the reasonableness of the citizenship grant
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Failure to assess credibility despite admitted misrepresentation
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Passport stamps, applicant's statements
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Prohibition of misrepresentation under the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Applicant misrepresented number of days absent from Canada
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Extent of unreported absences and lack of credibility analysis
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Passport evidence showing 799 days of absence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Compliance with residency and truthfulness requirements
Crimes.Application_Factor: Residency calculation and honesty in application
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False residency reporting in application documents

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making false representation for purposes of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Citizenship eligibility dispute involving false representation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge reasonably granted citizenship despite false representation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Lack of credible evidence supporting ties to Canada despite misrepresentation
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Passport records, application statements
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Offense of making false representations under the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: False claim of 360 days absent versus 799 days proven
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to meet physical residency requirement and false declaration
Crimes.Application_Error: Significant underreporting of absences from Canada
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of decision in light of legal requirements
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Clear documentary evidence of prolonged absences
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Requirement to meet residency either physically or through secondary tests
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Submission of materially false information in citizenship application
